intro: On their debut EP, LANco—fronted by namesake Brandon Lancaster—take the already-eclectic blueprint for mid-'10s country and mix it up even further with a dash of indie pop. But for all the layered guitar textures of "Long Live Tonight" and syncopated, electronically altered beats on "We Do," there are also moments like the romantic acoustic ballad "Greatest Love Story" and the bluesy roadhouse vibe of "Trouble Maker,” underlining the roots that remain part of LANco’s sound.

Six albums in, the veteran pop-rock outfit sounds fresher, freer, and more polished than ever. Red Pill Blues, a reference to The Matrix, finds them gliding effortlessly through slick staccato grooves (“What Lovers Do,” featuring SZA; “Don’t Wanna Know,” featuring Kendrick Lamar); lush, ’80s-inspired synths (“Who Am I,” featuring LunchMoney Lewis); and slow-rolling R&B (“Cold,” featuring Future). But frontman Adam Levine shines brightest on “Help Me Out,” an ambitious pop duet with Julia Michaels that shows off his remarkable vocal dexterity.

In Pt. 2, Rexha continues to blur genre lines and dish out hits. Hip-hop collaborations remain her sweet spot—Gucci Mane and 2 Chainz guest on “That’s It” and Lil Wayne croons over her carefree radio anthem “The Way I Are (Dance with Somebody)”—but she slips a few surprises in, too. Jamaica's Kranium sings on the dancehall duet “Comfortable” and Florida Georgia Line lend their radiant harmonies to “Meant to Be,” a country-pop smash designed to cross over.
track: The Way I Are (Dance With Somebody) [feat. Lil Wayne]
Meant to Be (feat. Florida Georgia Line)

intro: It’s subtle, but longtime Imagine Dragons fans will notice a newfound brightness on the Las Vegas band’s third album. That’s because frontman Dan Reynolds wrote most of it after coming out of a serious depression that had plagued him since childhood but became worse after the band’s 2015 world tour. Evolve marks his triumphant recovery. On arena anthems such as “Thunder” and “Start Over,” the band trades its signature angst for light rhythmic textures and fluid vocals about rebuilding. “Can we start over before it’s over?” Reynolds sings. “Come alive, come alive, come alive again.”
track: I'll Make It Up To You

intro: Released as singles, the defiant tropical house of “Hotter Than Hell” and “Lost In Your Light”’s love-giddy electro-pop have already established Dua Lipa as a pop powerhouse distinguished by her husky, soulful voice. Now, on a debut album inspired by past relationships, she gets to showcase her striking range. From the stinging dismissal of a remorseful ex (“IDGAF”) to a tender duet with Chris Martin (“Homesick”), the Londoner’s richly emotive singing and songwriting maintain her steeply upward trajectory.
Queen Bey hops on the remix.

Outgrowing the wild-hearted club anthems that defined her ascent, Kesha sounds reborn on her third album, commanding a set of sonically broad, heartfelt pop. Here, she punctuates the assertive funk of “Woman” with The Dap-Kings’ horn section and sings country-touched harmonies with Dolly Parton. But Rainbow is held together by Kesha’s elastic, giggle-to-roar vocal, which sounds best on blasting, jittery confections like “Boogie Feet” and “Learn to Let Go."
track: Let 'Em Talk (feat. Eagles of Death Metal)
Boogie Feet (feat. Eagles of Death Metal)
Old Flames (Can't Hold a Candle To You) [feat. Dolly Parton]

intro: Eighteen months after If I’m Honest detailed a tough, tabloid-drenched year, Texoma Shore paints a delightfully upbeat portrait of Shelton’s newly peaceful state of mind. The album is billed as a nostalgic tribute to small-town Oklahoma (“I Lived It,” “At the House”), but it’s equally heavy on pinch-me moments inspired, purportedly, by a certain red-lipped lady (“Turnin’ Me On,” “Why Me”). He sounds ready to recreate the bucolic bliss from his childhood on Lake Texoma. “You and me with the same street name/Same last name, same everything,” he sings on the splendidly sappy “I’ll Name the Dogs.” “Laying next to you every night/Sounds like a damn good life.”

album: The Thrill of It All (Special Edition)
intro: “Holy Father, we need to talk/I have a secret that I can’t keep.” Though it’s the first line of the fiery standout “HIM,” it’s a sentiment that sets the tone for The Thrill of It All, a diary-like album that has all the power and intimacy of a confession—as well as the catharsis that follows. Smith’s voice sounds as impressive as ever throughout. “Burning” is a spare, piano-led ballad inspired by the personal struggles that accompanied his breakthrough success. “Pray,” another gospel-informed stunner, soars with an uplifting choir and handclapped groove courtesy of Timbaland.

After appearing on The Chainsmokers’ fluorescent smash “Closer”, Halsey retreats into darkness. Opening with dialogue from Romeo and Juliet and full of intriguing narratives inspired by Halsey’s own heartbreak, hopeless fountain kingdom is a haunting concept album about doomed love. The Weeknd brings small-hours desperation to “Eyes Closed”, “Now or Never” is gorgeously fragile trap-soul and Halsey’s voice wobbles with self-flagellation on “Sorry”, a piano ballad that would fit snugly on an Adele album. It’s not all so elegantly muted though: “Walls Could Talk” successfully fuses punchy R&B with chamber music.

On a trip home to Alaska in 2016, frontman John Gourley stumbled upon his dad’s $8 Woodstock festival ticket stub. The discovery sparked an infatuation with ‘60s pop culture and its politically charged music. The band’s eighth album, a thrilling, gritty package of experimental pop-rock, is their take on music with a message. Loaded with deluxe production (thanks in part to Danger Mouse and Mike D), danceable energy (“Live in the Moment”), and poignant lyrics (“Noise Pollution”), it’s both a lively soundtrack to the resistance and a reminder to have fun.
track: Number One (feat. Richie Havens & Son Little)
Noise Pollution (feat. Mary Elizabeth Winstead & Zoe Manville) [Version A, Vocal Up Mix 1.3]

album: Faking It (feat. Kehlani & Lil Yachty) [Radio Edit] - Single
track: Faking It (feat. Kehlani & Lil Yachty) [Radio Edit]

intro: On her triumphant eighth album, Kelly Clarkson summons her inner Aretha. Trading her signature hook-laden pop-rock for gutsy soul, it’s a straight-talking, hater-shaking, hear-me-roar smash that shows off her superhuman range and vocal strength like never before. For the Nashville-based star, happiness is a happy marriage (“Meaning of Life”), an open mind (“Move You”), and a bulletproof self-confidence (“Go High”). But the highlight has to be “Whole Lotta Woman,” a rip-roaring collaboration with Earth, Wind & Fire that bulldozes bullies and body-shamers: “I ain't no girl/I'm a boss with orders.”

In 2016, Stevie Nicks introduced then 12-year-old Grace VanderWaal during the season finale of America’s Got Talent. “We like to be different,” Nicks said, “Not like anybody else.” It was high praise, and after winning the competition, VanderWaal got to work on Just the Beginning, her magnificent first full-length. A daring and gifted singer, she stretches her charismatic voice into hard-to-reach notes and octaves, exploring plucky textures (“Moonlight”), plush production (“Insane Sometimes”), and breathtaking acoustic balladry (“A Better Life”). She’s a natural, and startlingly fully formed. The album could easily be the product of someone twice her age and experience, and, to echo Nicks, it certainly couldn't be anybody else.

album: The Thrill of It All (Special Edition)
intro: “Holy Father, we need to talk/I have a secret that I can’t keep.” Though it’s the first line of the fiery standout “HIM,” it’s a sentiment that sets the tone for The Thrill of It All, a diary-like album that has all the power and intimacy of a confession—as well as the catharsis that follows. Smith’s voice sounds as impressive as ever throughout. “Burning” is a spare, piano-led ballad inspired by the personal struggles that accompanied his breakthrough success. “Pray,” another gospel-informed stunner, soars with an uplifting choir and handclapped groove courtesy of Timbaland.
Nothing can hold back the power of his voice and passion.

A contemporary pop spin on feel-good, windows-down country, Hero is the debut studio album from Maren Morris. The Texas native cut her teeth writing songs for Tim McGraw and Kelly Clarkson, but her fresh perspectives and knack for radio-ready pop hooks caught the attention of executives in Nashville, and earned her comparisons to crossover stars like Sheryl Crow and Kacey Musgraves. Fittingly, Hero includes Top 40 contenders, like the carefree anthem “80’s Mercedes,” alongside soulful country tributes like “My Church,” a ballad about Hank Williams, Johnny Cash, and the healing power of FM radio. “When this wonderful world gets heavy and I need to find my escape,” she sings, “I just keep the wheels rolling, radio scrolling, until my sins wash away.”
track: I Could Use a Love Song

intro: Exactly how pop and country should mingle.
track: Be Careful What You Wish For

intro: Flirty EDM-pop about love’s complexities.

On his third full-length, the English dynamo shows the full wealth and range of his powers. ÷ is a ruthlessly melodic run through a staggering array of styles, further proof that Sheeran is a singer/songwriter for these musical times: a balladeer who can blur the lines between Celtic folk and hip-hop (“Galway Girl”) just as readily as he can summon big, festival-ready sentiments (“Castle on the Hill”), impassioned serenades (“Perfect”), and pulse-quickening pop (“Shape of You.”)
Good-time anthems full of tender lyrics and rollicking choruses.

The Revivalists’ third album exudes the swampy, down-home flavor of previous efforts, yet the music also boasts a novel pop sensibility that’s equally delicious. Where “Fade Away” oozes the sweaty, Southern soul-rock that initially earned them a rabid fanbase, “Wish I Knew You” offers a whole new look, with David Shaw’s gruff croon dancing over sleek disco beats. The love-weary “Gold to Glass” goes further, thanks to its slinky Latin guitar licks and the kind of thumping bass that fuels modern R&B.
A fresh batch of feel-good songs about living in the moment.
track: Drink a Little Beer (feat. Rhett Akins)

intro: On his third full-length, the English dynamo shows the full wealth and range of his powers. ÷ is a ruthlessly melodic run through a staggering array of styles, further proof that Sheeran is a singer/songwriter for these musical times: a balladeer who can blur the lines between Celtic folk and hip-hop (“Galway Girl”) just as readily as he can summon big, festival-ready sentiments (“Castle on the Hill”), impassioned serenades (“Perfect”), and pulse-quickening pop (“Shape of You.”)

The good-time boys dig deep and add some reflection to the party-starters. After two incredibly popular (and raucous) albums that set the fuse on the “bro-country” movement, Tyler Hubbard and Brian Kelley dig deeper on their third album. “H.O.L.Y.” and “God, Your Mama, And Me” explore the pair’s faith, “Summerland” and “Island” are horizontal hits-in-waiting better suited to the after-party, and “Life Is a Honeymoon” indulges in some Ziggy Marley-assisted reggae.
track: Life Is a Honeymoon (feat. Ziggy Marley)
God, Your Mama, And Me (feat. Backstreet Boys)

intro: It’s subtle, but longtime Imagine Dragons fans will notice a newfound brightness on the Las Vegas band’s third album. That’s because frontman Dan Reynolds wrote most of it after coming out of a serious depression that had plagued him since childhood but became worse after the band’s 2015 world tour. Evolve marks his triumphant recovery. On arena anthems such as “Thunder” and “Start Over,” the band trades its signature angst for light rhythmic textures and fluid vocals about rebuilding. “Can we start over before it’s over?” Reynolds sings. “Come alive, come alive, come alive again.”
track: I'll Make It Up To You

intro: Outgrowing the wild-hearted club anthems that defined her ascent, Kesha sounds reborn on her third album, commanding a set of sonically broad, heartfelt pop. Here, she punctuates the assertive funk of “Woman” with The Dap-Kings’ horn section and sings country-touched harmonies with Dolly Parton. But Rainbow is held together by Kesha’s elastic, giggle-to-roar vocal, which sounds best on blasting, jittery confections like “Boogie Feet” and “Learn to Let Go."
track: Let 'Em Talk (feat. Eagles of Death Metal)
Boogie Feet (feat. Eagles of Death Metal)
Old Flames (Can't Hold a Candle To You) [feat. Dolly Parton]

intro: After a four-year absence, an epic, politically charged return.

Bruno Mars’ long-awaited return is one the most spirited, sonically cohesive, and danceable albums of 2016. Moving away from the New Wave flirtations of 2012’s chart-topping Unorthodox Jukebox, the singer/songwriter/musician fills 24K Magic with the feel-good vibes of ‘80s and ‘90s R&B. With the champagne-popping title track, epic slow jams (“Versace on the Floor”), and undeniable bops (“That’s What I Like”), Mars is a master of infectious pop. In other words, it’s Uptown Funk, The Album: a party-starting, jam-packed good time and further proof that Mars is at the top of his game.
A feature-heavy set showcasing the MC’s enviable dexterity.
track: Ain't Gonna Die Tonight (feat. Eric Nally)
How To Play the Flute (feat. King Draino)
Corner Store (feat. Dave B & Travis Thompson)

intro: First offered to fans as a surprise release through the mail, Church’s fifth album is an about-face from the bombastic explorations of 2014’s The Outsiders toward the kind of big, bittersweet country-rock that made ballads like “Springsteen” instant classics. Produced by longtime collaborator Jay Joyce (whose credits include Little Big Town and Carrie Underwood), Mr. Misunderstood is a hearty—and heartfelt—album, opening with a portrait of a good-natured outlaw who defies convention just by being himself (“Mr. Misunderstood”) and ending with a litany of lessons from a three-year-old boy, chief among them the importance of admitting when you’re wrong.
track: Mixed Drinks About Feelings (feat. Susan Tedeschi)

intro: A deep fusion of fierce reggaeton and intense Latin pop.

Khalid's soft-lit ‘80s synths and heartfelt, raspy vocal will catch your attention from the start, but his debut is most impressive for the effortless warmth and sincerity that lingers throughout. American Teen is all about summer sunshine, young love, and the adventures of tight-knit friends—subjects perfectly matched with the elegant blend of throwback R&B, ‘80s pop, and glitchy future-soul. The best tunes, openhearted ballads like “Saved” and “Shot Down,” are earnest without being overwrought and easily establish the songwriter as one of 2017’s most impressive newcomers.

track: You Don't Do It For Me Anymore

intro: On their sophomore album, the Nashville band delivers well-crafted, whimsical country songs with big hooks, wisecracks, and scores of metaphors. Thanks to frontman Matthew Ramsey’s slick cadence, every line sounds like a flirt. “How’s about some high heel, high top, pump 'em up, flip-flop/Heads up, lucky penny loafer on a sidewalk/Patent leather, blue suede, tailor-made, whatever you like,” he coos without missing a beat. “If you’re shoe shopping, try me on for size.” But even that’s no match for the electric “A Girl Is a Gun,” a witty word to the wise about the powers of women.
track: No Such Thing as a Broken Heart

intro: Bruno Mars’ long-awaited return is one the most spirited, sonically cohesive, and danceable albums of 2016. Moving away from the New Wave flirtations of 2012’s chart-topping Unorthodox Jukebox, the singer/songwriter/musician fills 24K Magic with the feel-good vibes of ‘80s and ‘90s R&B. With the champagne-popping title track, epic slow jams (“Versace on the Floor”), and undeniable bops (“That’s What I Like”), Mars is a master of infectious pop. In other words, it’s Uptown Funk, The Album: a party-starting, jam-packed good time and further proof that Mars is at the top of his game.

On her seventh studio album, P!nk achieves perfection. Featuring contributions from Jack Antonoff and longtime creative partner Billy Mann, Beautiful Trauma is a cathartic and wholehearted fusion of the personal and political. It begins with the piano-driven, Antonoff-produced thrills of the title cut and never wavers—from devastating ballads (“Barbies”) to festival-ready anthems for the disenfranchised (“What About Us”) and a devilish collaboration with Eminem (“Revenge”). The result is pop without filters: bold, frank, beautiful.

On his third full-length, the superstar shows the full wealth and range of his powers. ÷ is a ruthlessly melodic run through a staggering array of styles, further proof that Sheeran is a singer/songwriter for these musical times: a balladeer who can blur the lines between Celtic folk and hip-hop (“Galway Girl”) just as readily as he can summon big, festival-ready sentiments (“Castle on the Hill”), impassioned serenades (“Perfect”) and pulse-quickening pop (“Shape of You”).

Mothership is Jimmy Page’s hand-curated selection of the best of Led Zeppelin, and it’s the ultimate showcase of their proto-metal skills. The intuitive interplay between John Bonham’s drums and Page’s guitar riffs created some of the leanest hard rock on record—“Black Dog,” “Whole Lotta Love”—providing cocksure backup to Robert Plant’s lascivious screams. Equally skilled as bluesmen—“Since I’ve Been Loving You” is particularly aching—they reached a compositional peak in the Eastern strings of “Kashmir” and the folk-prog epic “Stairway to Heaven,” rock standards that retain an otherworldly power.
track: Over the Hills and Far Away

intro: On his third album, Dustin Lynch moves beyond the big ballads and bad-boy rockers that helped define his first couple albums. Here, Lynch offers a wide-ranging set of rock- and R&B-influenced country tunes (about half of which he wrote himself) that express a wide spectrum of emotions. There’s plenty of fun, clever writing on guitar-driven sing-alongs like “I Wish You Were Beer” and “Party Song,” but the songs that hit the hardest are catchy midtempo tracks like “Small Town Boy” and “New Girl."
track: Love Me or Leave Me Alone (feat. Karen Fairchild)
Sun Don't Go Down on That

intro: Under the guidance of executive producer Justin Timberlake—who sings on almost every track—Trolls is stacked with colorful, catchy melodies and playful pop-culture references. After launching to life with a Gwen Stefani-assisted “Hair Up” (which adds a maniacal dance beat to “In the Hall of the Mountain King”), the undeniable highlight is Timberlake’s infectious “CAN’T STOP THE FEELING!” Among the clever mash-ups and goofy lyrics, there are moments of genuine sweetness too, like Zooey Deschanel's heartfelt cover of Lionel Richie’s “Hello."
track: Move Your Feet / D.A.N.C.E. / It's a Sunshine Day
I'm Coming Out / Mo' Money Mo' Problems

intro: It's tempting to view The Weight of These Wings as Lambert's "divorce album" following her split from Blake Shelton, and songs like the acoustic, regret-laden "Pushin' Time" certainly lend credence to that notion. But this ambitious, double-length LP illustrates the full range of her talents. A roadhouse-rockin' cover of Danny O'Keefe's 1971 tune "Covered Wagon," the throbbing indie-pop beat of "Six Degrees of Separation," and the funky slow-burn of "Pink Sunglasses" only hint at the wide terrain traversed here.

Six albums in, the veteran pop-rock outfit sounds fresher, freer, and more polished than ever. Red Pill Blues, a reference to The Matrix, finds them gliding effortlessly through slick staccato grooves (“What Lovers Do,” featuring SZA; “Don’t Wanna Know,” featuring Kendrick Lamar); lush, ’80s-inspired synths (“Who Am I,” featuring LunchMoney Lewis); and slow-rolling R&B (“Cold,” featuring Future). But frontman Adam Levine shines brightest on “Help Me Out,” an ambitious pop duet with Julia Michaels that shows off his remarkable vocal dexterity.
Rarely do two stars harmonize so beautifully.

The bright-eyed Tennesseean returns with a glistening sophomore album about rebounding from breakups and the uncertainty of adolescence. In pensive, plush crossover ballads, she sings—with endearing self-awareness—about her experiences navigating the bumpy road to adulthood. “Sometimes I’m my mother’s daughter/Sometimes I’m her friend,” she reveals on “In Between,” a contemplative journal entry from age 24. “Sometimes I play grown-up/And sometimes I play pretend.” Don’t miss the tender song “High School,” a final tribute to childhood before joining the real world.
An unexpected banger that drips with hypnotic dancehall style.
It’s settled: Eldredge is country music’s biggest romantic.
Tender, twangy meditations on being all caught up in love.
track: Where I Go When I Drink

album: Let Me Go (feat. Florida Georgia Line & watt) - Single
track: Let Me Go (feat. Florida Georgia Line & watt)

intro: The fall from grace may be an established part of the reality narrative but The X Factor U.K winner James Arthur triumphantly flips the script on this energetically soulful second album. Personal turmoil—including an ongoing tussle with anxiety—proves the ultimate creative fuel. “Prisoner” is a bluesy hymn to self-destructiveness, “Phoenix” turns symbolic rebirth into a lusty neo-R&B cut and “Sermon”, featuring rapper Shotty Horror, is a fittingly confessional, gospel-tinged behemoth.
A bold but introspective debut LP from the Nashville firebrand.
track: You Ain't Here To Kiss Me

album: The Thrill of It All (Special Edition)
intro: “Holy Father, we need to talk/I have a secret that I can’t keep.” Though it’s the first line of the fiery standout “HIM,” it’s a sentiment that sets the tone for The Thrill of It All, a diary-like album that has all the power and intimacy of a confession—as well as the catharsis that follows. Smith’s voice sounds as impressive as ever throughout. “Burning” is a spare, piano-led ballad inspired by the personal struggles that accompanied his breakthrough success. “Pray,” another gospel-informed stunner, soars with an uplifting choir and handclapped groove courtesy of Timbaland.
An inspiring third album from the dexterous Michigan rapper.

Nashville’s one-man hit factory presses pause on the production line for a soulful solo debut. 13 years in the writing, the tracks on Traveller possess choruses as effortlessly infectious as anything Stapleton has gifted to high profile clients like Adele and Luke Bryan but there’s a fascinating desperation to the themes here. From the wild, sleepless delirium at the heart of “Parachute” to the bandit bluegrass on “Outlaw State of Mind”, this is country rock that’s unafraid to explore drink, drugs, and a very dark underbelly.
Feel-good crossover jams that are loaded with charm and wit.
track: You Look Like a Love Song

intro: Big-picture bids to live in the moment. And Warren Haynes.
track: What Keeps You up at Night
You Can't Help Who You Love
Story to Tell (Little Bird) [feat. Edwin McCain & Warren Haynes]

intro: Mariah Carey’s collection of soulful, seasonal pop is filled with Motown-flavored standards, playful R&B, and choir-backed gospel ballads. Carey co-wrote the album’s centerpiece, “All I Want for Christmas is You,” with longtime collaborator Walter Afanasieff, whose production uses a prancing beat, jangling sleigh bells, and sugar-sweet harmonies to evoke the feel of 1963’s A Christmas Gift for You from Phil Spector.
track: All I Want For Christmas Is You
Santa Claus Is Comin' To Town
Hark! The Herald Angels Sing / Gloria (In Excelsis Deo)
Jesus Oh What a Wonderful Child

album: Best Friend (feat. NERVO, The Knocks & Alisa Ueno) - Single
track: Best Friend (feat. NERVO, The Knocks & Alisa Ueno)

intro: On his third full-length, the English dynamo shows the full wealth and range of his powers. ÷ is a ruthlessly melodic run through a staggering array of styles, further proof that Sheeran is a singer/songwriter for these musical times: a balladeer who can blur the lines between Celtic folk and hip-hop (“Galway Girl”) just as readily as he can summon big, festival-ready sentiments (“Castle on the Hill”), impassioned serenades (“Perfect”), and pulse-quickening pop (“Shape of You.”)

Chris Stapleton follows his 2015 solo breakthrough—the CMA and GRAMMY®-winning Traveller—with an album that should appeal to every generation of country listener. Recorded in Nashville at RCA Studio A, the same legendary space where bearded forebears like Waylon Jennings and Willie Nelson cut classics, From A Room: Volume 1 is a spare yet soulful showcase for Stapleton’s remarkable voice, whether he’s rumbling through roadhouse rock ("Second One to Know”), showing his emotional range atop a gorgeous, fingerpicked guitar figure (“Either Way”), or harmonizing with his equally talented wife, Morgane (“Last Thing I Needed, First Thing This Morning”).
track: Last Thing I Needed, First Thing This Morning

intro: Who could resist a serenade this smooth?

This is the sound of world domination in 2017. Andrew Taggart and Alex Pall’s debut album comes after quite the storied introduction to their sound: two monster EPs and a summer-owning single (“Closer”) they were confident enough to leave off here. Memories… takes the band’s dynamite blueprint (retro synths and minor-key piano that softens up their explosive EDM) and adds some maturity. Opener “The One” feels like “Closer”’s broken-hearted sequel; Emily Warren’s two stately contributions add class; and the mellow “Wake Up Alone” features Jhené Aiko in masterly, seductive form.
track: Last Day Alive (feat. Florida Georgia Line)

intro: Mendes blossoms on his soulful second LP. Illuminate expands on the promise of the social media star’s 2015 debut (and his many online dispatches) with a set of introspective, blues-driven pop that recalls the guitar-born elegance of John Mayer (“Ruin” ) and the melodic verve of Ed Sheeran (“Three Empty Words”).
A feature-heavy set showcasing the MC’s enviable dexterity.
track: Ain't Gonna Die Tonight (feat. Eric Nally)
How To Play the Flute (feat. King Draino)
Corner Store (feat. Dave B & Travis Thompson)

intro: A fresh batch of feel-good songs about living in the moment.
track: Drink a Little Beer (feat. Rhett Akins)

album: Body Like a Back Road - Single

intro: An exhilarating debut from a rising Nashville star.
track: You Know Where to Find Me

intro: A bold but introspective debut LP from the Nashville firebrand.
track: You Ain't Here To Kiss Me

intro: The One Direction star makes his intentions crystal clear on this seriously sexy single. It draws heat from a club-friendly beat that allows Payne to indulge his deepest playboy fantasies. He flows like Ed Sheeran at his most raptastic, while Quavo of Migos takes the baton from Liam and sprints toward the finish.
A pop superstar. An enigmatic producer. The result? Magic.

The bright-eyed Tennesseean returns with a glistening sophomore album about rebounding from breakups and the uncertainty of adolescence. In pensive, plush crossover ballads, she sings—with endearing self-awareness—about her experiences navigating the bumpy road to adulthood. “Sometimes I’m my mother’s daughter/Sometimes I’m her friend,” she reveals on “In Between,” a contemplative journal entry from age 24. “Sometimes I play grown-up/And sometimes I play pretend.” Don’t miss the tender song “High School,” a final tribute to childhood before joining the real world.

When Sam Smith wails “I’m way too good at goodbyes,” you feel every ounce of heavy-lidded despair. The singer empties the tank on this ode to breakups. Its plaintive piano opens up to hopeful strings and a chest-filling chorus that puts the heart back together again. Smith does what he does best, putting simple words and complex feelings into lockstep, turning hurt into an act of redemption.
Bieber takes a verse in Spanish on this remix of the reggaeton hit.

On her seventh studio album, P!nk achieves perfection. Featuring contributions from Jack Antonoff and longtime creative partner Billy Mann, Beautiful Trauma is a cathartic and wholehearted fusion of the personal and political. It begins with the piano-driven, Antonoff-produced thrills of the title cut and never wavers—from devastating ballads (“Barbies”) to festival-ready anthems for the disenfranchised (“What About Us”) and a devilish collaboration with Eminem (“Revenge”). The result is pop without filters: bold, frank, beautiful.

Khalid's soft-lit ‘80s synths and heartfelt, raspy vocal will catch your attention from the start, but his debut is most impressive for the effortless warmth and sincerity that lingers throughout. American Teen is all about summer sunshine, young love, and the adventures of tight-knit friends—subjects perfectly matched with the elegant blend of throwback R&B, ‘80s pop, and glitchy future-soul. The best tunes, openhearted ballads like “Saved” and “Shot Down,” are earnest without being overwrought and easily establish the songwriter as one of 2017’s most impressive newcomers.
Exactly how pop and country should mingle.
track: Be Careful What You Wish For

intro: Whether rocking out electric (“Hometown,” “Pull it Off”) or settling down with an acoustic guitar (“Better Place”), Kane Brown does it with flavor and authenticity. His warm voice wraps around a track like a work glove and grips it tight. Filled with anthems and tear-jerkers, Kane Brown is a knockout of a debut album, and a likely forecast of even better things to come.

After the full-on assault of Led Zeppelin II, the band decided to take a step back and work through a milder approach for their third album. Guitarist Jimmy Page always had a deep interest in English folk music and while his reputation as one of rock’s most formidable electric lead guitar players was firmly established, he was also no slouch with the acoustic. The album opens on an anthemic note with the Nordic trample of “The Immigrant Song” and “Celebration Day” leading the heavy metal brigade. However, from the traditional “Gallows Pole” through the excited grace of “Bron-Y-Aur Stomp” and the genuine pastoral countryside shadings of “Tangerine” and “”That’s the Way,” Led Zeppelin nearly sound like a jam band. But the core of the group, Page and former ‘60s session extraordinaire John Paul Jones, perform with a deliberate mastery that captures the magic of the performance with the precision that can only be crafted in a carefully controlled studio. The group can veer near chaos (“Out On the Tiles”) and pull it back at just the right moment. Even in their quietest moments, their sense of tension leads them into further dimensions.

Six albums in, the veteran pop-rock outfit sounds fresher, freer, and more polished than ever. Red Pill Blues, a reference to The Matrix, finds them gliding effortlessly through slick staccato grooves (“What Lovers Do,” featuring SZA; “Don’t Wanna Know,” featuring Kendrick Lamar); lush, ’80s-inspired synths (“Who Am I,” featuring LunchMoney Lewis); and slow-rolling R&B (“Cold,” featuring Future). But frontman Adam Levine shines brightest on “Help Me Out,” an ambitious pop duet with Julia Michaels that shows off his remarkable vocal dexterity.

It’s subtle, but longtime Imagine Dragons fans will notice a newfound brightness on the Las Vegas band’s third album. That’s because frontman Dan Reynolds wrote most of it after coming out of a serious depression that had plagued him since childhood but became worse after the band’s 2015 world tour. Evolve marks his triumphant recovery. On arena anthems such as “Thunder” and “Start Over,” the band trades its signature angst for light rhythmic textures and fluid vocals about rebuilding. “Can we start over before it’s over?” Reynolds sings. “Come alive, come alive, come alive again.”
track: I'll Make It Up To You

intro: On his third full-length, the English dynamo shows the full wealth and range of his powers. ÷ is a ruthlessly melodic run through a staggering array of styles, further proof that Sheeran is a singer/songwriter for these musical times: a balladeer who can blur the lines between Celtic folk and hip-hop (“Galway Girl”) just as readily as he can summon big, festival-ready sentiments (“Castle on the Hill”), impassioned serenades (“Perfect”), and pulse-quickening pop (“Shape of You.”)
